intro: Luzula pallidula, commonly known as the pale sedge, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to temperate regions of the Northern Hemisphere. It belongs to the family Cyperaceae, which includes sedges and rushes, and is characterized by its triangular stems and narrow, grass-like leaves. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks. It produces small, inconspicuous flowers arranged in spikelets, which are clustered in dense inflorescences. Luzula pallidula is often used in ecological restoration projects due to its ability to stabilize soil and support local biodiversity.
